definitions: coming after ninety-nine others in a series or sequence; the ordinal number matching the number one hundred
examples: Today marks the hundredth anniversary of the historic event
She reached her hundredth birthday surrounded by family

definitions: feeling or showing the need for food; having an empty stomach
having a strong desire or craving for something, especially success or knowledge
examples: The hungry children waited eagerly for dinner
She felt hungry after skipping breakfast this morning
The young entrepreneur was hungry for success
He remained hungry for knowledge throughout his career

definitions: being chased or pursued as prey, especially by hunters or predators
showing fear or anxiety as if being pursued; having a worried, frightened appearance
examples: The hunted deer fled through the dense forest
Police searched for the hunted fugitive across state lines
She had a hunted look in her eyes after the ordeal
His hunted expression revealed his deep anxiety

definitions: done or acting with excessive speed or urgency, often carelessly
moving or acting quickly due to lack of time; characterized by haste
examples: She wrote a hurried note before leaving the office
Their hurried departure left many questions unanswered
The hurried passengers rushed to catch their flight
He made hurried preparations for the unexpected meeting

definitions: suffering from physical pain or injury to the body
experiencing emotional pain, distress, or offense from someone's actions or words
examples: The hurt athlete needed immediate medical attention
Her hurt ankle prevented her from running
He felt hurt by their harsh criticism
She looked hurt when they forgot her birthday

definitions: causing emotional distress, pain, or offense through words or actions
examples: His hurtful comments damaged their friendship permanently
She regretted saying such hurtful things in anger

definitions: characterized by silence or very low sound; quiet and subdued
deliberately made quiet or silenced, often to show respect or maintain secrecy
examples: They spoke in hushed tones during the ceremony
The hushed atmosphere in the library promoted concentration
The crowd became hushed when the verdict was announced
Her hushed voice conveyed the gravity of the situation

definitions: having a rough, deep quality of voice, often from emotion or illness
having a strong, solid build; burly and muscular in appearance
examples: His husky voice betrayed his emotional state
She spoke in husky whispers after the concert
The husky football player dominated the defensive line
Several husky workers loaded the heavy equipment

definitions: produced from or combining two different types, varieties, or species; having mixed characteristics
examples: The hybrid car uses both gasoline and electricity
Scientists developed a hybrid crop resistant to disease

definitions: having adequate water or moisture content; properly supplied with water or fluids
examples: Stay hydrated during exercise by drinking water regularly
The hydrated skin looked healthy and glowing

definitions: operated by or relating to the pressure of water or other liquids in motion
examples: The hydraulic lift raised the heavy machinery effortlessly
Modern aircraft use hydraulic systems for precise control

definitions: relating to or denoting the generation of electricity using flowing water to drive turbines
examples: The hydroelectric dam provides power for three cities
Countries with rivers often develop hydroelectric energy systems

definitions: tending to repel or fail to mix with water; having no affinity for water
having an extreme or irrational fear of water or inability to swim
examples: The hydrophobic coating keeps the surface completely dry
Scientists use hydrophobic materials in waterproof clothing
The hydrophobic patient refused to enter the swimming pool
Her hydrophobic reaction made beach vacations impossible

definitions: conducive to maintaining health and preventing disease, especially by being clean and sanitary
examples: The restaurant maintains hygienic food preparation standards
Hygienic practices prevent the spread of infections

definitions: abnormally or extremely active, restless, or unable to concentrate, especially in children
examples: The hyperactive child struggled to sit still during class
Sugar doesn't actually make children hyperactive despite popular belief

definitions: using deliberate and obvious exaggeration for emphasis or dramatic effect
relating to a hyperbola; having the mathematical properties of a hyperbolic curve
examples: His hyperbolic claims about the product were clearly marketing
She made hyperbolic statements about the minor inconvenience
The hyperbolic function appears frequently in physics equations
Students studied hyperbolic geometry in advanced mathematics

definitions: having abnormally high blood pressure; relating to or suffering from hypertension
examples: The hypertensive patient required daily medication
Hypertensive individuals should monitor their salt intake carefully

definitions: tending to produce sleep; having a sedative or soporific effect
fascinating or holding attention in an almost magical way; mesmerizing
examples: The doctor prescribed hypnotic medication for severe insomnia
The hypnotic effect of the drug lasted eight hours
The dancer's hypnotic movements captivated the entire audience
The hypnotic rhythm of the waves calmed her mind

definitions: placed in a hypnotic trance through hypnosis or suggestion
completely fascinated or absorbed; unable to look away or think of anything else
examples: The hypnotized patient responded only to the therapist's voice
She remained hypnotized throughout the therapeutic session
The audience sat hypnotized by the brilliant performance
He seemed hypnotized by her beauty and charm

definitions: behaving in a way that contradicts stated beliefs or feelings; pretending to have higher standards than one actually has
examples: His hypocritical criticism ignored his own similar mistakes
It seems hypocritical to preach values you don't follow

definitions: relating to the region immediately beneath the skin; used for injections under the skin
examples: The nurse prepared a hypodermic needle for the injection
Hypodermic administration ensures rapid drug absorption

definitions: based on or serving as a hypothesis; assumed or imagined for the purpose of reasoning or argument
examples: Let's consider a hypothetical situation where resources are unlimited
The professor posed hypothetical questions to test understanding

definitions: affected by or deriving from wildly uncontrolled emotion, especially fear or panic
extremely funny; causing uncontrollable laughter or amusement
examples: The hysterical crowd fled from the burning building
She became hysterical when she heard the terrible news
The comedian's hysterical performance had everyone laughing
We watched a hysterical movie that left us in tears

definitions: relating to or using iambs, a metrical foot of two syllables with stress on the second
examples: Shakespeare wrote many plays in iambic pentameter
The poem follows a strict iambic rhythm throughout

definitions: widely recognized and established as being representative of something; having achieved legendary status
relating to or of the nature of an icon, especially a religious image
examples: The iconic photograph captured a defining moment in history
She became an iconic figure in the fashion industry
The museum displayed iconic religious art from medieval times
These iconic images hold deep spiritual significance

definitions: attacking or criticizing cherished beliefs, traditional institutions, or established values; revolutionary in approach
examples: Her iconoclastic views challenged the academic establishment
The iconoclastic artist rejected all conventional techniques

definitions: covered with or consisting of ice; extremely slippery from ice
extremely cold in temperature; freezing or near freezing
showing no friendliness or warmth; hostile and emotionally cold
examples: Drive carefully on the icy roads this morning
The icy sidewalk caused several people to slip
An icy wind blew across the frozen lake
Her hands felt icy after working outside
She gave him an icy stare and walked away
His icy reception made everyone uncomfortable

definitions: satisfying one's conception of what is perfect; most suitable or excellent
existing only in the imagination; desirable but not likely to become reality
examples: This location offers ideal conditions for growing grapes
She found the ideal partner who shares her values
In an ideal world, poverty wouldn't exist
The proposal describes an ideal situation that's impractical

definitions: regarded or represented as perfect or better than reality; viewed through rose-colored glasses
examples: She had an idealised memory of her childhood
The painting shows an idealised version of rural life

definitions: characterized by idealism; unrealistically aiming for perfection or holding high principles
examples: The idealistic young lawyer wanted to change the world
His idealistic proposals ignored practical constraints

definitions: regarded or represented as perfect or better than reality; viewed through rose-colored glasses
examples: He had an idealized view of marriage before reality hit
The movie presented an idealized version of the 1950s

definitions: exactly alike in every detail; having no differences when compared
examples: The identical twins confused even their parents sometimes
These two documents contain identical information

definitions: able to be recognized or distinguished; capable of being identified or established
examples: The suspect had several identifiable features witnesses remembered
Each product contains identifiable markings for quality control

definitions: recognized or established as being a particular person or thing; determined or discovered
examples: The identified suspect was arrested within hours
Scientists identified several new species this year

definitions: based on or relating to a system of ideas and ideals, especially political or economic theory
examples: The parties have deep ideological differences on taxation
Their ideological commitment shaped every policy decision

definitions: using expressions natural to a native speaker; characteristic of a particular language's idioms
examples: Her idiomatic English impressed the interview panel
The translation captures the idiomatic expressions perfectly

definitions: relating to distinctive or peculiar individual characteristics; unusual in a way specific to a person
examples: His idiosyncratic teaching style either delighted or frustrated students
She had an idiosyncratic way of organizing her files

definitions: extremely stupid or foolish; showing a complete lack of intelligence or common sense
examples: It was idiotic to drive in such dangerous weather
His idiotic mistake cost the company thousands of dollars

definitions: not active or in use; not working or operating
avoiding work; lazy or without purpose or effect
having no factual basis; groundless or without foundation
examples: The idle machinery gathered dust in the warehouse
Several workers stood idle during the power outage
He spent idle hours browsing social media
Don't waste time on idle pursuits
These are idle threats with no real consequence
She dismissed it as idle gossip

definitions: admired or loved greatly, often excessively; regarded as perfect or as a hero
examples: The idolized actor could do no wrong in fans' eyes
She idolized her older sister throughout childhood

definitions: extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque; like an idealized rural paradise
examples: They spent an idyllic weekend at the countryside cottage
The idyllic setting made it perfect for a wedding

definitions: relating to rock formed by solidification of molten magma or lava
examples: Granite is a common igneous rock found in mountains
The volcanic island consists mainly of igneous formations

definitions: caught fire or caused to burn; set alight
triggered or aroused intense emotion or action; sparked something
examples: The ignited gasoline spread quickly across the floor
The ignited match fell onto dry leaves
Her speech ignited passion in the crowd
The scandal ignited public outrage

definitions: lacking knowledge, information, or awareness about something in particular
discourteous or rude; showing lack of social awareness or sensitivity
examples: She remained ignorant of the changes until yesterday
Many people are ignorant about basic nutrition
His ignorant comments offended everyone at the table
Don't be so ignorant towards other cultures

definitions: deliberately paid no attention to; disregarded or refused to acknowledge
examples: The ignored warnings led to serious consequences
She felt hurt by his ignored messages

definitions: suffering from illness or disease; not in good health
harmful, hostile, or unfavorable; causing or indicating trouble
examples: She felt too ill to attend the meeting
The ill patient needed immediate medical attention
He harbored no ill feelings toward his rival
The company could ill afford another scandal

definitions: contrary to or forbidden by law; not authorized or sanctioned by official rules
examples: Parking here is illegal without a permit
The company engaged in illegal business practices

definitions: not clear enough to be read; impossible to decipher due to poor handwriting or print
examples: His handwriting was completely illegible to everyone
The illegible signature caused problems at the bank

definitions: not authorized by law or rules; not in accordance with accepted standards
born of parents not married to each other; historically considered socially unacceptable
examples: The court ruled the election illegitimate due to fraud
They condemned the illegitimate use of force
In Victorian times, illegitimate children faced social stigma
The illegitimate heir couldn't inherit the title

definitions: forbidden by law, rules, or custom; illegal or improper
examples: Police discovered an illicit drug operation downtown
Their illicit affair destroyed both marriages
